items.title: Palestinian committee set to govern Gaza under U.S. supervision meets in Cairo
items.summary_auto: The Palestinian committee set to govern Gaza under U.S. supervision met for the first time Friday in Cairo, as its leader pledged to get to work quickly to improve conditions there.

items.title: Calgary lifting all water restrictions effective immediately
These fully grown sea lions won't not stop nursing, and scientists don’t know why
items.summary_auto: A new study documents the surprising prevalence of 'supersuckling' among Galápagos Islands sea lions.

items.title: Bo Bichette, Mets agree to $126M US, 3-year contract: reports
items.summary_auto: Blue Jays homegrown star Bo Bichette is leaving Toronto for the New York Mets, according to media reports. The Associated Press and ESPN report the deal is for $126 million US over three years.

items.title: Kathleen Kennedy, steward of major expansion in the Star Wars universe, steps down from Lucasfilm
items.summary_auto: After more than 13 years at the helm of Lucasfilm, Kathleen Kennedy is stepping down from the Star Wars factory founded by George Lucas.

items.title: WestJet reversing move to install tight seating layout
items.summary_auto: In the wake of a backlash sparked by a viral video, WestJet has cancelled a new seat configuration that squeezed an extra row on board many of its planes and left passengers with less legroom.

items.title: What’s behind all those pistachio recalls?
items.summary_auto: For months, the Canadian Food Inspection Agency has pulled hundreds of items containing pistachios from shelves over possible salmonella contamination. Some retailers are choosing to avoid even unrecalled pistachio products altogether until the situation stabilizes.

items.title: Amid crisis in Kashechewan First Nation in northern Ontario, a tough choice: melt ice for water or leave others behind
items.summary_auto: Life is quieter in Kashechewan First Nation in northern Ontario. Some children can still be seen playing hockey on a snow-packed road, but that would have been more common three weeks earlier had the community's water-treatment plant not failed. Amid a state of emergency, about half of the 2,300 residents have already been evacuated to cities including Timmins, Kingston and Niagara Falls.

items.title: Hundreds gather to mourn Trevor Dubois who died after fight with Sask. hospital security
items.summary_auto: Hundreds gathered in Prince Albert to mourn social worker and advocate Trevor Dubois, remembered for his warmth, humor and community impact.

items.title: Ontario premier slams Canada’s 'lopsided' new EV deal with China
Big, barking, bellowing sea lions back in B.C.'s Howe Sound
items.summary_auto: "It's almost like a biker gang convention. They just arrive out of nowhere, they cause havoc, they’re barking and belching,” said UBC fisheries professor Andrew Trites.

items.title: Canadian track cyclist-turned-bobsledder Kelsey Mitchell in pursuit of her 3rd Olympics
items.summary_auto: This coming weekend, Canada's bobsleigh team will compete in Altenberg, Germany for its last chance to qualify a sled at the Milano Cortina Olympics beginning Feb. 6. Kelsey Mitchell, an Olympic track cycling champion who made the switch to bobsleigh in recent months, is hoping it will be her ticket to Milano Cortina.

items.title: Exiled Reza Pahlavi positions himself as ready to lead Iran, as protests within country appear to ebb
items.summary_auto: Iran's deadly crackdown appears to have broadly quelled protests for now, according to a rights group and residents, as state media reported more arrests on Friday in the shadow of U.S. threats to intervene if the killing continues.

items.title: Canada's Mboko defeats Australia's Birrell for spot in Adelaide International final
items.summary_auto: Canada's Victoria Mboko is onto the Adelaide International women's tennis final. The 19-year-old from Toronto defeated Australia's Kimberly Birrell 6-2, 6-1 in the semifinals on Friday to advance.

items.title: Federal government loses Emergencies Act appeal, court says use during convoy protest was unreasonable
items.summary_auto: The Liberal government unreasonably invoked the Emergencies Act to clear the convoy protests that gridlocked the capital city and border points nearly four years ago, the Federal Court of Appeal said.

items.title: PQ leader says Legault's resignation further evidence of need for independent Quebec
items.summary_auto: Paul St-Pierre Plamondon says François Legault's resignation is proof that trying to build a strong Quebec within Canada doesn't work.

items.title: RCMP applicants endured 'improper and invasive' medical exams for years, lawsuit alleges
items.summary_auto: One thousand RCMP employees, past and present, allege as part of a class-action lawsuit headed to Federal Court this month, that they were subjected to "improper and invasive" breast, genital and rectal exams during mandatory medical screening, CBC News has learned.

items.title: Are you overpaying for a lab-grown diamond?
items.summary_auto: Marketed as an alternative to mined diamonds, lab-grown stones are growing in popularity among engaged couples, taking some of the shine from mined or “natural” diamonds, which have traditionally dominated the market.

items.title: Former South Korea leader handed 5-year jail term for charges related to martial law
items.summary_auto: The Seoul Central District Court found the ex-president guilty of mobilizing the presidential security service to block authorities from executing an arrest warrant that had been legally issued by a court to investigate him ​for his martial law declaration.

items.title: Canada reaches tariff-quota deal with China on EVs, canola
items.summary_auto: The Liberal government has reached a deal with Beijing to allow tens of thousands of Chinese electric vehicles into the domestic market in exchange for dropping duties on canola products, Prime Minister Mark Carney said Friday.

items.title: Long lineups in central Alberta to sign petition for province to leave Canada
items.summary_auto: Large crowds of people lined up around the block outside a pair of packed community halls in central Alberta on Wednesday night, to attend town meetings focused on the idea of the province seeking independence from Canada.
